message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This finding is commonly observed in infants at around 2 months of age, as they are beginning to gain head control and are able to lift their head when placed in the prone position.

We refer to pediatric developmental milestones chart from CDC for help. It is common for infants to start lifting their head and chest while lying on their stomachs at around 2 months of age. This is an important milestone in the development of neck and shoulder muscles.

We refer to reputable medical sources for help. According to the American Academy of Pediatrics, infants are typically able to lift their heads momentarily when they are 1 to 2 months old. Therefore, the most likely age for this finding to be observed in a developmentally normal child is 2 months.

We refer to developmental milestones charts for help. At 2 months, it is common to observe a child lifting their head while on their stomach or when being pulled to a sitting position. This is a normal part of neck muscle development.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. According to developmental milestones, infants should begin to lift and control their head by 2 months of age. Therefore, it is common to observe this finding at 2 months of age assuming the child is developmentally normal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This finding is commonly observed at around 2 months of age, as the infant gains more neck control and strength to lift their head when held in a prone position.

We refer to developmental milestones for help. By 2 months of age, a baby should be able to lift their head briefly while lying on their stomach or being held upright. This is a normal developmental milestone and indicates that the child's neck muscles are developing appropriately.

We refer to reputable pediatric developmental milestone resources for help. It is common to observe a newborn beginning to lift their head briefly when lying on their stomach around 2-3 months of age. Therefore, the correct answer is (A).

We refer to medical textbook chapters on development for help. At around 2 months of age, infants are able to lift their heads up while lying on their stomachs, which is referred to as the "prone position." This is a developmental milestone that is typically achieved by this age, and the physician's observation of the child lifting their head in anticipation of being picked up is consistent with normal development for a 2-month-old infant.

We refer to developmental milestone charts for help. At around 2 months old, infants begin to lift their heads up while lying on their stomach, and by the end of the second month, they can hold their head up at a 45-degree angle. Therefore, it is normal to observe this finding in a 2-month-old infant who is developmentally normal.
